wikipedia_page.main: Tom Keetley (16 November 1898 – 18 August 1958) was an English professional footballer who played as a centre forward. He scored 284 Football League goals between 1919 and 1934.

response: |Highest Scorer in One Season||Tom Keetley, 39, Division Three South 1930–31

The first match back in the Football League was a 0–0 draw against Wigan Borough at Belle Vue on 25 August 1923, with Rovers playing in red tops with white shorts. One of the players in that first match was Rovers legend Tom Keetley who went on to become the Club's highest scorer with 186 goals in 241 appearances. Doncaster ended the season in 9th place. The next few seasons saw them rise towards the top of the table, then decline towards the bottom, before in the early 1930s finishing consistently near the top and finally becoming Champions in 1934–35.

The road around the Doncaster Rovers stadium opened in 2006 was named Alick Jeffrey Way, whilst five apartment blocks built on the site of the former Doncaster Rovers ground at Belle Vue were named after five of the Rovers' greatest ever players - Alick Jeffrey, Walter Langton, Tom Keetley, Syd Bycroft and James Coppinger.

response: After he retired from football, he settled in Derbyshire and was the owner of the Rose & Crown Inn at Chellaston near Derby. Following his retirement, the licensee was Tom Keetley who had had a long football career with Doncaster Rovers and Notts County.Discover Derby: Chellaston
